newsitem.title: USA: Western Resources seen winning Kansas City Power.
newsitem.headline: Western Resources seen winning Kansas City Power.

text.p: Kansas City Power & Light Co. could become the first U.S. utility to fall to a hostile takeover after a lack of shareholder support forced it to abandon its $1.7 billion merger agreement with UtiliCorp United Inc.

Rival bidder Western Resources Inc. is now expected to sweep up Kansas City Power, capping a successful raid against the company and potentially spurring a new wave of hostile utility mergers, industry analysts said.
Kansas City Power, based in Kansas City, Mo., said Wednesday it failed to win shareholder approval for its proposed merger with Utilicorp, also based in Kansas City.

KCP&L is still playing defence since it is opposed to Western's $1.9 billion offer, but analysts say Western has already won over KCP&L shareholders in its five-month takeover battle and will likely succeed.
A source close to KCP&L said the company is still recommending shareholders not tender their shares to Western.
KCP&L shareholders must now weigh Western's offer of $31 of its stock per KCP&L share.
In trading Thursday, Kansas City Power was unchanged at $27.25 a share, Utilicorp was up 12.5 cents at $28 a share, and Western was up 12.5 cents at $29 a share, all on the New York Stock Exchange.
Western said if a majority of the shareholders back the deal, but the directors balk, they are prepared to nominate their own slate of directors who will approve the merger.
The offer expires Oct. 25 but can be extended by Western if necessary.
Meanwhile, Wall Street was already buzzing over which would be the next utility to attract an unwanted bidder.
"It's a brave new world out there and hostile takeovers are now a part of that," said Penelope Adelmann, Gruntal & Co. utility analyst.
"It certainly opens up the hostile as another possibility. I think it will be a trend," said Linda Byus, Nesbitt Burns utility analyst.

"It is significant industrywide because it shows shareholders now have a say. Historically, utility retail shareholders -- the moms and pops, widows and orphans -- have gone along with management. But this is a wakeup call that managements work for shareholders," Byus said.
But Adelmann noted hostile takeovers do not suit every company.

"When Western has a particular goal in mind, they go after it strongly. So hostile takeovers take a particular type of management, and there are not many like Western. With a hostile, you have got to use your own management (in the post-deal company) and feel you can make it with your own people."
A recent issue of the Utility Forecaster newsletter identified some potential takeover targets, including Citizens Utilities Co., Energen Corp. and Central Louisiana Electric.

Six weeks ago, another hostile offer was announced. MidAmerican Energy Co., based in Des Moines, Iowa, launched a bid to break up a friendly three-way merger by offering $1.2 billion in cash and stock, or $39 per share, for IES Industries Inc., of Cedar Rapids, Iowa.
IES agreed last fall to combine with Interstate Power Co. of Dubuque, Iowa, and WPL Holdings Inc. of Madison, Wis.
One of the few hostile utility mergers previously attempted -- all have failed -- included Western's predecessor company and KCP&L.
Five years ago, KCP&L made a hostile run at Kansas Gas and Electric Co., but Kansas Power & Light came in as a white knight and merged with KGE to create Western Resources.

Roger Conrad, editor of the Utility Forecaster newsletter, said KCP&L's decision to back out of the UtiliCorp pact has "enormous implications because if the Western deal comes off, it shows utilities don't necessarily need the approval of the other board to launch a takeover. So we will see more of these types of deals, or at least more pressure to enter negotiations."
